blog.name: brieflydoods
blog.title: ART IS MY PASSION
blog.description: Hi my name is Kay! Any pronouns are a-okay. My main blog for reblogs is Brieflykawaii, my main art blog is Brieflydoodles, and this was my former art blog, now random shit blog where I kinda just throw?? whatever I want. I'll probs reblog my art stuff here to promote it but also make all my silly thought posts here so it doesn't clutter up my art blog!! Thanks for following if you do :D

title: Hurt!Aziraphale prompts
body:
because we need more angel suffering damn it

1. By the time Crowley makes it to the church, Aziraphale has been shot and the Nazis are preparing to burn him alive

2. (SPN AU) Selected angels are sacrificed in order to bring forth a new divine creature, Sam and Dean hear news about people dying out of nowhere while surrounded by rather abnormally large feathers, meanwhile in London, Aziraphale starts to grow weak, only way to stop it, is to kill the creature.

3. Crowley accidentally burns Aziraphale but the angel thinks it was on purpose and avoids him, unaware that the injury will only keep spreading if Crowley doesn’t stop it

summary: So I got the book Good Omens and every time the word "ineffable" comes up I'm putting a blue sticky note on the page. Everytime...
body: So I got the book Good Omens and every time the word “ineffable” comes up I’m putting a blue sticky note on the page. Everytime Crowley and Aziraphale are cute, I put a yellow sticky note on the page. Cant wait to see how many sticky notes there are after I finish reading

summary: about aziraphale being fat and old and also the hottest thing crowley has ever known
title: about aziraphale being fat and old and also the hottest thing crowley has ever known
body:
i keep starting and stopping this post in my head, so i’m just gonna write it down. now, i’ll be very clear from the get-go: there is certainly a value in being attracted to a lover’s personality, to the light that shines in their eyes, the soft curve of their lip, the sound of their laugh, the way they hold their hands, the way they say “i love you”, their fastidious and funny little ways, their stupid jokes, etc, etc.

this post is not about that. there’s often a tone re: aziraphale’s weight that kind comes across as, “oh, but crowley is still attracted to him bc of his personality,” like YEAH, that, but also, his body. you don’t need to go, ”oh it’s all about his personality”, like, his body is GREAT 

so, let’s define the aziraphale that i’m talking about here. let’s say, from an average person’s POV, he looks to be in his mid-fifties, which is one thing on its own. like, people can have… wrinkles. these can be sexy. laughter lines, crow’s feet, everpresent dimples. they’re marks of wear and tear, sure, but that’s where the expression is: a smile laid that valley around his mouth; his laughter created those lines at his eyes; his cute little concentrated frown made that furrow in his brow. 

 and he is, shall we say… well-proportioned? he’s fat. that’s what we mean: that’s what we’ll say. he’s fat. this does not, in fact, mean that he’s super skinny, with skinny legs and skinny arms, and like, a slightly rounded belly, no.

he’s meaty. if you start from his shoulders, he will be broader. you won’t see his collarbone from across the room, sharp enough to cut glass. the flesh settles thick on the bones, gives it all the cushioning it needs. his breast is not all that flat: it’s warm and fat and pillowy on each side, and then he has the round curve to his belly. but the thing is, like… when you’re chubby and you have that rounded form, it isn’t just a little curve in the front: it’s heavy on the sides, too, and cushions the hips.

because of the way our bodies gather fat, you’re not gonna have two straight lines for legs: aziraphale’s thighs will be super generously proportioned, but his calves will be less so, and most of the fat will land around his seat - his arse (it’s absolutely a fat arse, o yes), and the tops of his thighs. his arms will have the same kind of thing - they’ll be thicker in the upper arm than in the forearm. there’ll also probably be more wobble to the thighs and the upper arms than to the calves and to the forearms.

and his hands!!! plump hands! so soft! 

there’s a tendency, when it comes to bodies that are fat, to avert the gaze. we look away, because there’s this overwhelming narrative of thin bodies being the only good bodies, and we’re subsequently quite uncomfortable with bodies that aren’t slender or like, muscled. bc there’s that conditioning to look away from fat bodies, to see them as ugly or inherently unhealthy, when neither is true whatsoever, we also tend to desexualise fat bodies, and i defo think that that’s maybe part of the reason there’s that big thing of like, focusing on aziraphale as thinner and conventionally handsome. 

crowley does not have that tendency. he does not look at aziraphale’s body and think that he should be thinner. crowley’s lifetime has spanned a multitude of epochs, and the connotations of aziraphale’s body might have been calculated to deter any mortals that might want to come onto him, but they sure as fuck can’t deter crowley. 

listen. 

aziraphale’s body is hefty. it’s meaty. 

it’s a body that says, in a language far older than magazines and television and advertisements for not-meals, “yes, i eat and drink and i lead a life of indolence, bc i can.” his hands are soft and plump and pretty: aziraphale doesn’t work outside, doesn’t labour and doesn’t toil. he does soft, inside work, and he’s genteel. his body is fat and pillowy: crowley can reach out and grab fistfuls of his lovehandles, feel the flesh yield beneath his touch; he can playfully smack aziraphale’s thigh, watch it jiggle and quake under the light blow; he can feel aziraphale’s weight on him, pinning him down no matter how strong he really is. when he smiles, there are dimples: his cheeks are round and rosy, his lips are plump. 

when crowley lies on him, he radiates warmth, and he’s never cold: he’s soft and comfortable, and when he hugs crowley, he surrounds him. 

like, if you jump back about 500, 1000 years, 1500 years, AND FURTHER, aziraphale is a fucking catch. he’s fat - means he’s rich, means he doesn’t work outside too much! yes, he’s got a few years on him, but that just means he won’t run off and fuck around elsewhere! he’s got soft hands, a warm body, a warmer bed, no doubt, and like, listen, he’s got all his own teeth and everything!

aziraphale can be fat and old and sexy!

(and he is! crowley will say so!)

tags: idk if u have gleaned this
but i'm emo about greenhouses and i Love Them
summary: let crowley have a greenhouse. let him grow plants underneath the glass panes, the sun shining down on luscious, verdant leaves,...
body:
let crowley have a greenhouse.

let him grow plants underneath the glass panes, the sun shining down on luscious, verdant leaves, the scent of the air like ozone: let him remember what eden was, surrounded on every side by viridian splendour, the scent of heat and air and mulch and blossom thick on his tongue. let him stand, at times, in the middle of it all, leaning against his potting table, feeling naught more than the warmth of a sun he once knew millennia ago, the first time it kissed black scales and gave him a scant sliver of the warmth he knew with the Host

let him have his greenhouse.

let him love in it, and laugh in it: let him whisper dark threats to tomatoes and cucumbers, let him murmur evil words to the leaves of pepper plants, let him leave burning words on the skin of every chilli, that it grows riper and heavier with every day that passes.

let him stand in his greenhouse when the rain is falling, so that he can close his eyes and hear the thunder of every drop upon the glass panes, and feel, for just a moment, as if the world is ending.

and let aziraphale come up behind him, press a kiss to his shoulder, and say, “come inside, dear. it’s getting late.”

let him leave his eden behind him, every night, and follow the angel where he leads.

reblog.comment:

let him love in it, and laugh in it: let him whisper dark threats to tomatoes and cucumbers, let him murmur evil words to the leaves of pepper plants, let him leave burning words on the skin of every chilli, that it grows riper and heavier with every day that passes.

let him stand in his greenhouse when the rain is falling, so that he can close his eyes and hear the thunder of every drop upon the glass panes, and feel, for just a moment, as if the world is ending.

and let aziraphale come up behind him, press a kiss to his shoulder, and say, “come inside, dear. it’s getting late.”

let him leave his eden behind him, every night, and follow the angel where he leads.

trail.content_raw:
let crowley have a greenhouse.

let him grow plants underneath the glass panes, the sun shining down on luscious, verdant leaves, the scent of the air like ozone: let him remember what eden was, surrounded on every side by viridian splendour, the scent of heat and air and mulch and blossom thick on his tongue. let him stand, at times, in the middle of it all, leaning against his potting table, feeling naught more than the warmth of a sun he once knew millennia ago, the first time it kissed black scales and gave him a scant sliver of the warmth he knew with the Host

let him have his greenhouse.

let him love in it, and laugh in it: let him whisper dark threats to tomatoes and cucumbers, let him murmur evil words to the leaves of pepper plants, let him leave burning words on the skin of every chilli, that it grows riper and heavier with every day that passes.

let him stand in his greenhouse when the rain is falling, so that he can close his eyes and hear the thunder of every drop upon the glass panes, and feel, for just a moment, as if the world is ending.

and let aziraphale come up behind him, press a kiss to his shoulder, and say, “come inside, dear. it’s getting late.”

let him leave his eden behind him, every night, and follow the angel where he leads.
trail.content:
let crowley have a greenhouse.

let him grow plants underneath the glass panes, the sun shining down on luscious, verdant leaves, the scent of the air like ozone: let him remember what eden was, surrounded on every side by viridian splendour, the scent of heat and air and mulch and blossom thick on his tongue. let him stand, at times, in the middle of it all, leaning against his potting table, feeling naught more than the warmth of a sun he once knew millennia ago, the first time it kissed black scales and gave him a scant sliver of the warmth he knew with the Host

let him have his greenhouse.

let him love in it, and laugh in it: let him whisper dark threats to tomatoes and cucumbers, let him murmur evil words to the leaves of pepper plants, let him leave burning words on the skin of every chilli, that it grows riper and heavier with every day that passes.

let him stand in his greenhouse when the rain is falling, so that he can close his eyes and hear the thunder of every drop upon the glass panes, and feel, for just a moment, as if the world is ending.

and let aziraphale come up behind him, press a kiss to his shoulder, and say, “come inside, dear. it’s getting late.”

let him leave his eden behind him, every night, and follow the angel where he leads.

tags: that's longer then intended but i don't have time to edit now
and its not worth going back to later
summary: So while we’re all on about the Eden scene, the thing about the "funny if we both got it wrong” line is that it could have been...
body:
So while we’re all on about the Eden scene, the thing about the “funny if we both got it wrong” line is that it could have been played a number of ways. It could be a passing joke, an anxious observation, a thoughtless comment recanted the next moment, a deliberate attempt to mess with Aziraphale.

But it also has the potential to be weighted with meaning, to be a revolutionary statement about who they are and what they are capable of, and an invitation to be delighted by the freedom instead of threatened by it. If pointedly and earnestly meant, it is a statement that reaches across the divide, that says, “I think perhaps we are not so different. Could you accept that?”

Then that Eden clip dropped and Crowley says the line with That smile and welp! Guess we’re going for the ‘weighted with meaning’ route, then! And yes Aziraphale pulls back, ostensibly refuses the invitation, but first he laughed. Because he’s not ready to face the implications of genuine freedom, not yet, not for 6000 years, but on a some level he not only already believes it but feels the joy of it. That and also Pretty Demon Smiled Nice and frankly he’s a bit flustered.

And so it goes. Aziraphale keeps saying the correct things, keeps telling himself he believes them. “You’re a demon, I’m an angel,” he says, “we do this, we can’t do that.” But his laughter is the true predictor of his actions. “Come in and have a drink just as you are, my demon friend. Tell me your anxieties and I’ll tell you mine. Let me help you with your work, we can lighten one another’s burdens. For we are the same, you and I. I will not say it, not even in private, but I will live by it.”

reblog.comment:

But it also has the potential to be weighted with meaning, to be a revolutionary statement about who they are and what they are capable of, and an invitation to be delighted by the freedom instead of threatened by it. If pointedly and earnestly meant, it is a statement that reaches across the divide, that says, “I think perhaps we are not so different. Could you accept that?”

Then that Eden clip dropped and Crowley says the line with That smile and welp! Guess we’re going for the ‘weighted with meaning’ route, then! And yes Aziraphale pulls back, ostensibly refuses the invitation, but first he laughed. Because he’s not ready to face the implications of genuine freedom, not yet, not for 6000 years, but on a some level he not only already believes it but feels the joy of it. That and also Pretty Demon Smiled Nice and frankly he’s a bit flustered.

And so it goes. Aziraphale keeps saying the correct things, keeps telling himself he believes them. “You’re a demon, I’m an angel,” he says, “we do this, we can’t do that.” But his laughter is the true predictor of his actions. “Come in and have a drink just as you are, my demon friend. Tell me your anxieties and I’ll tell you mine. Let me help you with your work, we can lighten one another’s burdens. For we are the same, you and I. I will not say it, not even in private, but I will live by it.”

trail.content_raw:
So while we’re all on about the Eden scene, the thing about the “funny if we both got it wrong” line is that it could have been played a number of ways. It could be a passing joke, an anxious observation, a thoughtless comment recanted the next moment, a deliberate attempt to mess with Aziraphale.

But it also has the potential to be weighted with meaning, to be a revolutionary statement about who they are and what they are capable of, and an invitation to be delighted by the freedom instead of threatened by it. If pointedly and earnestly meant, it is a statement that reaches across the divide, that says, “I think perhaps we are not so different. Could you accept that?”

Then that Eden clip dropped and Crowley says the line with That smile and welp! Guess we’re going for the ‘weighted with meaning’ route, then! And yes Aziraphale pulls back, ostensibly refuses the invitation, but first he laughed. Because he’s not ready to face the implications of genuine freedom, not yet, not for 6000 years, but on a some level he not only already believes it but feels the joy of it. That and also Pretty Demon Smiled Nice and frankly he’s a bit flustered.

And so it goes. Aziraphale keeps saying the correct things, keeps telling himself he believes them. “You’re a demon, I’m an angel,” he says, “we do this, we can’t do that.” But his laughter is the true predictor of his actions. “Come in and have a drink just as you are, my demon friend. Tell me your anxieties and I’ll tell you mine. Let me help you with your work, we can lighten one another’s burdens. For we are the same, you and I. I will not say it, not even in private, but I will live by it.”
trail.content:
So while we’re all on about the Eden scene, the thing about the “funny if we both got it wrong” line is that it could have been played a number of ways. It could be a passing joke, an anxious observation, a thoughtless comment recanted the next moment, a deliberate attempt to mess with Aziraphale.

But it also has the potential to be weighted with meaning, to be a revolutionary statement about who they are and what they are capable of, and an invitation to be delighted by the freedom instead of threatened by it. If pointedly and earnestly meant, it is a statement that reaches across the divide, that says, “I think perhaps we are not so different. Could you accept that?”

Then that Eden clip dropped and Crowley says the line with That smile and welp! Guess we’re going for the ‘weighted with meaning’ route, then! And yes Aziraphale pulls back, ostensibly refuses the invitation, but first he laughed. Because he’s not ready to face the implications of genuine freedom, not yet, not for 6000 years, but on a some level he not only already believes it but feels the joy of it. That and also Pretty Demon Smiled Nice and frankly he’s a bit flustered.

And so it goes. Aziraphale keeps saying the correct things, keeps telling himself he believes them. “You’re a demon, I’m an angel,” he says, “we do this, we can’t do that.” But his laughter is the true predictor of his actions. “Come in and have a drink just as you are, my demon friend. Tell me your anxieties and I’ll tell you mine. Let me help you with your work, we can lighten one another’s burdens. For we are the same, you and I. I will not say it, not even in private, but I will live by it.”

summary: Do you guys think that sometimes when Aziraphale is getting annoyed while reading a book the story in it changes by itself?...
body: Do you guys think that sometimes when Aziraphale is getting annoyed while reading a book the story in it changes by itself? Like, say he’s reading a romance and he’s starting to get frustrated with all the pining, the “getting together at the last possible second” story turns, to its own surprise, into about 50k of fluff without Aziraphale realizing that’s his influence? Or does Crowley do it for him when he sees the angel frowning and Aziraphale to this day hasn’t noticed?

reblog.comment: Do you guys think that sometimes when Aziraphale is getting annoyed while reading a book the story in it changes by itself? summary: THE J STANDS FOR JANELLE MONAE
title: THE J STANDS FOR JANELLE MONAE
body:
I must write a fic based loosely on the premise of Make Me Feel immediately

And by immediately I mean in about three months once I’m not frantically packing for my holiday, cramming a coursework deadline, trying to do continued professional development balls, working a nine day week until my holiday and then cramming for an exam I didn’t even realise I was actually having but I will be thinking about this concept every spare moment until then

summary:
They went to the Ritz again, where a table was mysteriously vacant. And perhaps the recent
exertions had had some fallout in the...
body:
They went to the Ritz again, where a table was mysteriously vacant. And perhaps the recent exertions had had some fallout in the nature of reality because, while they were eating, for the first time ever, a nightingale sang in Berkeley Square.

~ Good Omens by Terry Pratchett & Neil Gaiman

reblog.comment:
